thinking.disposable_income: Hermosa has a median household income of $66,073, with about 38% of households earning less than $50,000 annually. This suggests moderate disposable income levels, making residents sensitive to both transit fares and sales tax increases.
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With a per capita income of $27,053 and average household size of 3.1, discretionary spending is likely limited. Many households need to carefully balance transportation costs with other essential expenses.
thinking.accessibility: 87.5% of households own at least one vehicle, with 60.9% driving alone to work and 17.7% using transit. This indicates a car-dependent community but with significant transit usage, suggesting need for balanced transportation options.
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritized proposals with lower sales tax (0.5%) to protect discretionary income. 2. Favored moderate transit fares ($1.25) to maintain transit affordability while supporting service quality. 3. Supported moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without overly burdening the majority who drive. 4. Balanced travel time improvements for both transit and car users. 5. Considered the large Hispanic population (80.1%) who may have varied transportation needs and income levels.
